snippet: No costumes or copies -- but items from the past like evening tail coats and narrow pants are enriching the men's wear future.
lead_paragraph: PARIS -- Formal headgear, evening tail coat, small vests, narrow pants and red brick prints -- it does not take Sherlock Holmes to work out that men's fashion for 2012 is tipping its broad-brimmed hat to the 19th century. Even Comme des Garçons referenced the gothic on Friday with a whimsical show of dark androgyny: all wild black hair weeping under black hats and tailored clothes that gave an elegant edge to the dark side.

headline.main: A Hint of Victoriana

snippet: Is there anything Google can't find? In February the popular search engine announced that it had started indexing millions of portable document format files (identifiable by the suffix .pdf). Now the company has launched Google Image Search, a nifty...
lead_paragraph: Is there anything Google can't find? In February the popular search engine announced that it had started indexing millions of portable document format files (identifiable by the suffix .pdf). Now the company has launched Google Image Search, a nifty new tool that lets you search for the pictures embedded in Web pages. Scouring more than 150 million images, Image Search (images.google.com) turns up some real gems. For example, it found more than 2,500 images in a search for ''Bill Gates,'' including corporate head shots, the mug shot from a 1977 traffic arrest and an image taken seconds after he was hit in the face with a pie a few years ago.
abstract: Search engine Google launches Image Search, new tool allowing users to search for pictures embedded in Web pages; photo (S)

headline.main: A Quick Way to Search For Images on the Web

lead_paragraph: Q. Why don't the pictures taken from orbiting spacecraft, on the Moon, etc., show any stars in the background? A. Some such pictures do show stars, and NASA offers a Web link to one that does: eol.jsc.nasa.gov/Images/STS039-342-25.jpg. For the most part, however, pictures taken by astronauts are in the nature of snapshots, intended to capture some well-lighted object in the foreground, like Earth or another astronaut.

snippet: The versatile Wii Remote can be snapped inside a steering wheel or guitar, so why not a graphics tablet? The uDraw GameTablet ($70) is a 4 inch by 6 inch drawing tablet that rests on your lap.  When used with uDraw Studio, the included disk, children...
lead_paragraph: The versatile Wii Remote can be snapped inside a steering wheel or guitar, so why not a graphics tablet? The uDraw GameTablet ($70) is a 4 inch by 6 inch drawing tablet that rests on your lap. When used with uDraw Studio, the included disk, children can draw pictures with charcoal or opaque water colors. This is no Wacom tablet. There's a slight lag when splotching paint, and you can't import digital photos. But you can export projects in JPG format to an SD card, and there's a mesmorizing replay feature that reviews paintings, one stroke at a time. So, if your kids don't like what's on TV, they can draw their own.
abstract: Gadgetwise blog; Udraw GameTablet allows children to use Nintendo Wii gaming system to draw pictures; costs $70 (M)

lead_paragraph: Jeans have been stone-washed, bleached, unbleached and shredded. They've come 'n every shade of blue, plus black, red, green, yellow, orange and pink. They've come in leather, suede, velvet, corduroy and cotton shirting. Now, look for white denim jeans, which are what many members of the fashion flock were wearing at the fall collections. White jeans had a miniflurry a few years ago and, like many fashions of the past, are having a revival. The Gap's classic white denim jeans, which come in regular, long or ankle l'ngth, are $29; late in the month there will be a Capri style with a low waistband, at $38.

headline.main: By Design;Once More for White Jeans

snippet: Q. Our computers are connected to the Internet by a cable modem and a Linksys wireless access point. I want to buy a new cordless phone, but I am worried that it may disrupt the network. Are there cordless phones that use a frequency that will not...
lead_paragraph: Q. Our computers are connected to the Internet by a cable modem and a Linksys wireless access point. I want to buy a new cordless phone, but I am worried that it may disrupt the network. Are there cordless phones that use a frequency that will not interfere with the wireless network? A. The most common wireless networks for home users, 802.11b and g, can sometimes interfere with some cordless telephones because they use the 2.4-gigahertz frequency to broadcast signals from the base station to a computer or handset. Other devices like baby monitors or older microwave ovens can also disrupt a wireless network. Although interference from other electronic products may not block the wireless network signal entirely, it can make the network slow and balky.

headline.main: Q & A

snippet: The billboard high above East 86th Street near Third Avenue could make pedestrians look up and scratch their heads at the same time. There's something odd about the subway car that Beth Israel and St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospitals used to give a...
lead_paragraph: The billboard high above East 86th Street near Third Avenue could make pedestrians look up and scratch their heads at the same time. There's something odd about the subway car that Beth Israel and St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospitals used to give a distinct New York flavor to this ad celebrating their partnership. The ad, which has been up for a month, was produced by an advertising agency whose staff looked through hundreds of stock photographs to find a representative example of a New York subway train. But Joseph P. Brennan, a rail buff who is a computer specialist at Columbia University, took a closer look after people began asking where that subway car was really from. His verdict: ''That's definitely not New York. It looks like the Chicago el.'' Sure enough, he found a Web site (http://members.aol.com/chictafan/p3200.jpg) where you can see a twin of this car. The billboard was scheduled to be up for six months, but now that word of Mr. Brennan's discovery is out, the ad will be replaced in a couple of weeks. ''It's a chance for us to include our new partnership with Long Island College Hospital,'' said Kathleen McGovern, vice president for public affairs and marketing at Beth Israel and St. Luke's Roosevelt. And the subway car pictured, she said, will be changed to one that is ''clearly a New York City train.'' MICHAEL MOLYNEUX
abstract: Officials at Beth Israel and St Luke's-Roosevelt Hospitals plan to change picture on NYC billboard celebrating their partnership after rail buff Joseph P Brennan notes photo is not one of NYC subway car; photo (M)

headline.main: Next Stop . . . the Loop

lead_paragraph: Dispelling concerns over a possible liquidity squeeze, Pinault-Printemps-Redoute, the French retailer, said today that it had agreed to sell the mail- order division of its Guilbert office- supplies unit to Staples of the United States for 825 million euros ($809 million). The sale removes Pinault from the mail-order office-supply market, though it will continue direct sales to business customers. It also advances the strategy of Pinault's chief executive, Serge Weinberg, who has been shedding assets to ease investor concerns over the 6 billion euros ($5.8 billion) in company debt coming due in the next two years. In April, Standard & Poor's cut the credit rating for Pinault's bonds to just above junk status, citing the heavy debt load.
abstract: Pinault-Printemps-Redoute agrees to sell mail-order division of its Guilbert office-supplies unit to Staples for 825 million euros ($809 million); sale removes Pinault from mail-order office-supply market, though it will continue direct sales to business customers (M)

snippet: A City Room design contest: Won't you help burnish the image of 1 World Trade Center? Or would you rather work on Freedom Tower?
lead_paragraph: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has a big problem. And we think City Room readers will have an answer. The problem: How do you market the tallest skyscraper at the World Trade Center site to prospective tenants? When readers were reminded last week that the authority had -- largely for leasing reasons -- quietly been replacing the symbolic name "Freedom Tower" with the more prosaic (but also symbolic) "1 World Trade Center," hundreds of comments followed. Many included alternative name suggestions; about which, more in a moment.This week, we'd like more than comments. Following the terrific response to our 2007 exercise in taxi logo redesign, we hope the designers among you -- amateur and pro -- will consider drawing up a hypothetical logo proposal for the new building. Image files in JPG or GIF formats are preferable, sent as e-mail attachments to cityroom@nytimes.com by 5 p.m. Friday. You're free to use whatever building name suits you, but please relate the appearance of the logo to the words. (We've prepared a few examples, to the left and below, of what we're talking about.) The best logos will be displayed on City Room next week. There is no reward other than the satisfaction of seeing your work on the site. To learn more about the building, visit the Port Authority's Web site.
abstract: A City Room design contest: Won't you help burnish the image of 1 World Trade Center? Or would you rather work on Freedom Tower?

lead_paragraph: Q. I am a Macintosh user, and I had assumed that any JPEG file was accessible to anyone. But friends with PC's are having trouble opening picture files that I send to them. What can I do? A. The JPEG format (short for Joint Photographic Experts Group) is a common type of image file and is used extensively for Web pages and pictures taken by digital cameras. With its tight compression standard, the format makes it possible to squeeze a color photograph into a file small enough to be e-mailed or downloaded from a Web site without consuming a lot of time or space.

As a finale to the show devoted to the stars of the silver screen, there were projections of the famous faces quivering on the backdrop: Jean Harlow, Mae West, Louise Brooks, Veronica Lake and Rita Hayworth, whose hairstyle was dramatically recreated on the runway as russet coils above a perky shorts suit.

Do I need to be concerned about viruses and network security the way I would with an Internet-connected computer? A. Windows-based computers are still major targets for virus writers and other Internet prowlers, but a few pieces of malicious software specifically aim at hand-held organizers, smartphones and other mobile devices. Once any device is connected to the Internet, it becomes possible -- although still somewhat unlikely at this point -- to pick up a worm or virus.

snippet: THE more megapixels the merrier -- or so you'd gather from digital camera prices. The higher the number of megapixels, the more expensive the camera will be in comparison with others with similar features. But what are megapixels? How many do you...
lead_paragraph: THE more megapixels the merrier -- or so you'd gather from digital camera prices. The higher the number of megapixels, the more expensive the camera will be in comparison with others with similar features. But what are megapixels? How many do you need? Is more always better? Pixels (known as megapixels when you count them by the million) are picture elements, the tiny spots of data that make up a digital image. All photos are made up of tiny elements: from the ink dots in newspaper photos to the grains of silver or particles of color dye in film photography. A good photo usually has millions of these elements. The more there are, the sharper and more detailed the picture is, and the harder it is to distinguish the elements from one another.
abstract: Ivan Berger Basics column discusses terminology and use of digital cameras; explains relationship of megapixels and resolution, cropping on the camera or PC, memory and formats; photo (M)

snippet: THE last two years, I have met guys at dinner parties, through friends and at my local bar. And I have shown either really bad judgment or had spectacularly bad luck. I have gone out with or been pursued by two gay men who thought they were straight,...
lead_paragraph: THE last two years, I have met guys at dinner parties, through friends and at my local bar. And I have shown either really bad judgment or had spectacularly bad luck. I have gone out with or been pursued by two gay men who thought they were straight, a guy just out of prison, someone who preferred opium to sex, two amorous mechanics and a wealthy widower who was 77 and had two other girlfriends. At a wedding I met a good-looking, well-educated divorced guy who was a good dancer. The bride told me he was a cross-dresser. So I turned to the Internet personals. At least the Internet would give me access to heterosexual men in my age bracket (somewhere between middle age and out, out brief candle) who had avoided jail, drugs, bigamy and cross-dressing. And it offers speed. If I went onto the site late on a Saturday night, I would find dozens of guys waiting at their monitors, eating a slice of pizza and hoping to hook up -- that night.
abstract: Linda Lee View column unravels secret code that men use in computer personal ads (M)

snippet: The somber colors and covered-up styles of the summer 2012 men's shows in Paris seem to echo Europe's dreary weather.
lead_paragraph: PARIS -- With rain clouds racing over the skies of Europe and a shivery chill after the unexpected highs of April, menswear designers are looking visionary. The dark side of summer is reflected in the Paris collections for spring 2012, and the star of the shows is the superlight raincoat. Subdued colors and patterns -- like Adam Kimmel's black-dyed Hawaiian prints -- express a general mood not of gloom, but of restraint.

headline.main: Let It Rain! The Dark Side of Summer
ARMY ORDERS

byline.original: Special to The New York Times

snippet: For regular travelers with eager shutter fingers, storage gadgets can be more economical than additional memory cards.
lead_paragraph: PROLIFIC digital photographers are subject to a pair of technology trends working at cross-purposes. Price drops have made high-capacity memory cards affordable for everyday use. But new consumer cameras that offer up to eight megapixels of resolution make rapidly escalating demands on storage memory. That may not matter when photos can be transferred easily from the camera to a computer. But travelers, wildlife photographers and others face undesirable choices. They can set their cameras to lower resolution, sacrificing overall image quality, to squeeze more pictures onto a memory card. They can invest in more cards. Or they can lug a laptop computer along.
abstract: Basics Basics column on hand-held devices that can take on burden of overstuffed memory cards in digital cameras; photos (M)

snippet: Digital cameras are taking billions more pictures than anyone wants to see. The notion is finally dawning that perhaps less may still be more.
lead_paragraph: THE baby pictures just kept coming. At least once a month Suzanne Weber opened her e-mail to find the same friend had sent a link to as many as 50 pictures, often including multiple shots of the same child at the same moment at slightly different angles. Finally Ms. Weber, who enjoys the occasional digital baby snapshot as much as anyone, stopped responding, and the friend, taking the hint, stopped sending. Ms. Weber's e-mail, however, is by no means picture-free. Like many regular Internet users, she estimates that she will view more than 1,000 (why stop? it's free) digital pictures this year of friends, family and their assorted offspring. And she has some unequivocal advice for snap-happy e-mail correspondents everywhere.
